title: Ransomware Hackers Demand $70 Million to Unlock Computers in Widespread Attack
summary: Kaseya CEO tells White House there is no evidence that critical infrastructure was impacted by attack on some of his company's customers. The boss of the company at the heart of a widespread hack that has affected hundreds of businesses said he briefed the White House and that attackers are demanding a single $70 million ransomware payment.

title: Israeli Vote on Citizenship for Palestinians Tests New Government
summary: Law effectively bars Israeli Arabs from extending citizenship to spouses from the occupied Palestinian territories. TEL AVIV-Israel's parliament remained deadlocked late Monday over a temporary law that bars citizenship for Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and Gaza who are married to Israelis, the latest issue to challenge the new fragile coalition government.

title: Global Stocks Mixed, U.S. Futures Waver
summary: U.S. markets were closed for the July 4 holiday, and S&P 500 futures pointed to tepid decline at the market open Tuesday. Global stocks were mixed Monday, with U.S. markets closed for the July 4 holiday and futures pointing to a muted trading session at the open Tuesday.

title: Former Honduran Executive Convicted in Killing Environmental Activist
summary: Berta Cáceres, murdered in 2016, led an effort to stop a dam project on indigenous lands. A Honduran court convicted the former chairman of a local construction company Monday of ordering the 2016 assassination of Berta Cáceres, an indigenous-rights leader and environmental crusader whose killing shocked the world.

title: In OPEC Deadlock, U.A.E. Steps Out of Saudi Shadow
summary: U.A.E., which has deviated from its bigger neighbor in regional issues, is now at odds with Riyadh over oil policy. OPEC failed in its third attempt to resolve a deadlock over oil production after divisions between allies Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates spilled into public and into global financial markets.

title: Defund Joe Biden's IRS
summary: The president calls the extra $80 billion for the agency an 'investment.'. Joe Biden may be mistaken about many things, but he's right about the Internal Revenue Service. If the IRS is to become the agency he wants it to become, it needs the $80 billion in extra funding he is now proposing.

title: Antitrust Can Hurt U.S. Competitiveness
summary: Actions against RCA, AT&T and Xerox gave a leg up to European and Japanese firms.. When it comes to technology and the economy, the U.S. is grappling with two contradictory goals: competing with China in advanced technology industries and ramping up antitrust enforcement against leading U.S. tech companies.

title: 'Coping With Defeat' Review: Believers Without Borders
summary: What the fall of empires, the rise of nations and the spread of diasporas have meant for Sunni Islam and Roman Catholicism.. In July 1900, after a wave of attacks against civilians and politicians in Europe and America, an Italian anarchist who had been living in Paterson, N.J., murdered the king of Italy. In November 2015, Muslims from Molenbeek, Belgium (and elsewhere), killed 130 innocent people in Paris. In both cities, immigrant revolutionaries had pursued their global political agendas against the governments of their old and new homes alike. Faced with poverty, police surveillance and disproportionately high incarceration rates, some in these communities saw militancy as a legitimate form of politics and undertook several spectacular acts of international violence to advance their cause.

title: Big Tech and Big Finance Breed Hubris
summary: With their 'pretense of knowledge,' BlackRock and Facebook make it harder to find the truth.. The suppression of debate over the origin of the novel coronavirus highlights a broader problem. Governments were once the chief impediments to free speech and free markets, but extremely large private companies may have become the greater danger. These hyperscale firms serve as hubs and gateways in the highly networked knowledge economy. They are well-positioned to exert special control over information-and other companies.

title: The Fed Is Underestimating the Risk of Inflation
summary: The data suggest prices will continue to increase, but the bank is guilty of faulty analysis.. Economists routinely make mistakes in forecasting, and such mistakes are often forgiven. But recent errors by the Federal Reserve are deeper analytical blunders. As with any activity that claims to have professional status, economics must respect elementary arithmetic.

title: Notable & Quotable: Pride in the U.S.A.
summary: 'Which is the one-and only one-demographic group in the I&I/TIPP poll that is not proud to be American?'. IssuesAndInsights.com reporting on poll released July 5:

title: England on Track to Lift Most Covid-19 Curbs
summary: Leader says country is on track to end restrictions on July 19. LONDON-U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson said England was on track to lift almost all Covid-19 restrictions as planned on July 19, even as the highly transmissible Delta variant of coronavirus drives a new surge in infections.

title: Mexico Hands Control of Large Oilfield to Pemex in Dispute With U.S.'s Talos
summary: The decision against private operator comes as López Obrador administration seeks to curb opening of energy sector. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's government designated state oil company Petróleos Mexicanos as the operator of a large offshore oil reservoir it shares with a consortium led by Houston-based Talos Energy Inc., which has already invested heavily in the reservoir.

title: At Bagram, the Lights Went Out and the Afghans Found Themselves Facing the Taliban Alone
summary: Resume Subscription. BAGRAM AIRFIELD, Afghanistan-Afghan soldiers returned to their barracks to prepare for dinner last Friday when all the generators suddenly fell silent and the lights on this massive base, the centerpiece of America's war effort in Afghanistan, shut off.

title: Lina Khan's Power Grab at the FTC
summary: The new Chair snatches unilateral authority and rescinds bipartisan Obama-era standards.. Independent federal agencies have power over American life that the Founders never imagined, and that reign is about to expand with a vengeance in the Biden era. Witness the unprecedented power grab engineered last week at the Federal Trade Commission by the new chair, Lina Khan.

title: Drop the Georgia Election Lawsuit
summary: The suit is an all but certain loser in light of Brnovich v. DNC.. Attorney General Merrick Garland is the front-runner so far for 2021's bad timing prize. The Justice Department last month rushed out a lawsuit claiming that Georgia's new election law violates Section 2 of the 1965 Voting Rights Act only days before the Supreme Court laid down standards that make the lawsuit a nearly certain loser.

title: The Cruise Industry Destruction Act
summary: An 1886 protectionist law gives Canada power over Alaskan tourism.. When Canada in February temporarily banned cruise ships from its ports because of Covid-19, Alaska's congressional delegation blasted the move. They said the decision threatened the Alaska cruise industry. What they didn't mention is that the reason this industry is at the mercy of Canada is because of U.S. law.

title: July Fourth Delivers Huge Crowds, but Who's Complaining?
summary: Independence Day saw people across the country eager to enjoy a regular holiday weekend. This weekend, Firemen's Park in Waterloo, Wis., had an estimated 3,000 visitors at its peak, about 1,000 more than pre-pandemic holidays.

title: Gen Z's Unlikely Home Decor Obsession: DIY Rugs
summary: Resume Subscription. Nicholas Ferrara never intended to become a rug maker.

title: Chinese Regulators Suggested Didi Delay Its U.S. IPO
summary: Ride-hailing giant, under pressure to reward shareholders, pushed ahead with NYSE listing despite concerns of China's cybersecurity watchdog. Weeks before Didi Global Inc. went public in the U.S., China's cybersecurity watchdog suggested the Chinese ride-hailing giant delay its initial public offering and urged it to conduct a thorough self-examination of its network security, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Variant Hits Unvaccinated Nations Hard
summary: Infections are surging in countries such as Indonesia, as the epicenter of the Covid-19 pandemic moves to the developing world. SINGAPORE-The fast-spreading Delta variant of the coronavirus is driving up infections in developing countries that are dangerously short on Covid-19 vaccines to battle deadly surges and whose healthcare systems are struggling to cope.

title: Flaws Emerge in Justice Department Strategy for Prosecuting Wall Street
summary: A Barclays fraud case shows how a push to target financial-industry wrongdoers can run into resistance from judges. Early one July morning in 2016, Robert Bogucki, a senior executive at Barclays PLC, walked into what he expected to be a short meeting with the British bank's lawyers to go over a five-year-old transaction before he joined his family on vacation.

title: There's Good Election News-Except in New York
summary: An election-fraud rebuttal, a victory for integrity, and hopeful signs that voting patterns are changing.. Democrats and the media have a simple rule about disputed elections: When Democrats complain about the result, there must have been something profoundly wrong with the process that rendered the outcome unreliable: dodgy ballots (Al Gore, Florida, 2000), corrupt machinery (John Kerry, Ohio, 2004), voter suppression (just about every election Democrats have lost in the south in the last 30 years but especially Stacey Abrams, Georgia, 2018).

title: A Four-Step Money Plan for College Graduates
summary: Wealth should reflect your contentment with your life, your choices and the resources you must manage in order to enjoy it.. Lazetta Rainey Braxton is the co-CEO of 2050 Wealth Partners in New York

title: Volkswagen Ejects Supercar Bugatti as It Shifts to EVs
summary: Storied brand will be controlled by Croatia's Rimac as German auto giant moves away from combustion engines. BERLIN- Volkswagen AG is selling the Bugatti hypercar business to create a new company jointly owned by the Croatian electric car startup Rimac Automobili and VW's sports car unit Porsche AG , as the auto industry's pivot to electric vehicles transforms the elite world of super high-performance sports cars.

title: Biden to Temper U.S. Use of Sanctions Weapons
summary: Administration to veer from Trump policies, spurring a debate about economic leverage over adversaries. The Biden administration is revamping the way the U.S. uses punitive sanctions, aiming to stem sweeping pressure campaigns, avoid collateral economic damage and act jointly with allies rather than unilaterally, according to people involved in the planning process.

title: How Long Might the Next Bear Market Last?
summary: The fear is that today's high valuations will mean a long decline. But bear markets don't necessarily work that way.. Many investors worry that the stock market's current overvaluation means that the next bear market-whenever it begins-will be a long and deep one.

title: What Sharon Stone Is Most Looking Forward to Post-Pandemic
summary: The 'Basic Instinct' and 'Casino' star is lucid dreaming, taking baths in Dead Sea salts and wondering whether her outspokenness has hurt her standing in Hollywood.. Sharon Stone loves to sleep. The actor and author, 63, who lives in Los Angeles, wakes up at the last possible minute ahead of her first meetings and obligations. She makes her bed, takes a quick shower and throws on a bit of makeup. She's usually figured out what she's going to wear the night before. Then it's right to her home office or car, and the day begins-and no two are the same. "Nothing is set in my world," she says of having a schedule that changes daily. "I usually bring my meditation ball and throw it in my bag, and just kind of do everything where there's a space."

title: Private Equity Spots Bargains in U.K. Supermarket Aisles
summary: A bidding war is brewing for property-rich grocery chain WM Morrison only a few months after Walmart's partial exit from the British market. Walmart executives must be upset. Months after the retail giant sold a majority stake in its British grocery chain Asda at a mediocre valuation, U.K. supermarkets are suddenly hot property among private-equity firms.

title: Almonds Swept California Farms. Then the Water Ran Out.
summary: Resume Subscription. As another severe drought takes its toll in California, some farmers are backing away from one of their most profitable crops: almonds.

title: Taliban Find New Revenues as They Seize Border Gateway
summary: U.S. spent over $40 million on Afghanistan-Tajikistan crossing. Now the Taliban is collecting customs revenues. KABUL-The Taliban have gained a lucrative new source of income, taking over the main trade gateway into Tajikistan, and beginning to collect customs revenues, as some of Afghanistan's neighbors tacitly cooperate with the insurgent group.

title: Critical Race Theory Inside the U.S. Military
summary: Which Americans will raise their hands and pledge an oath to 'support and defend' our Constitution if they're taught it's inherently racist?. Your editorial "Has the Military Gone 'Woke'?" (June 26) illustrates well the threat that critical race theory poses to our armed forces.

title: Tony Hayward, Who Led BP During Gulf Spill, to Retire as Glencore Chairman
summary: Departure caps the changing of the guard at the commodities giant after CEO stepped down last week. LONDON-Tony Hayward, who stepped down leading BP PLC in the wake of the fatal Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, is retiring as chairman of Glencore PLC, the commodities giant he presided over for eight years.

title: Supply, Demand and Your Crazy Utility Bill
summary: Renewables subsidies, goals and mandates have undercut reliable baseload power generation.. Regarding "Huge Winter Gas Bills Spark Anger, Action" (U.S. News, June 28): Renewables subsidies, goals and mandates have undercut reliable baseload power generation (primarily from hydrocarbons) and distorted the market. Consumers are overreliant on intermittent power-generation sources such as wind that sometimes aren't there when we need them most. Meanwhile, most natural gas is sold based on monthly average price contracts, not spot price. Natural-gas producers saved tens of thousands of lives this winter, but they didn't set prices or reap windfalls. Like farmers and ranchers, they take the price set by regional and global markets. The market signals were a vast and lengthy wind drought plus extreme demand for home heating and natural-gas power generation. The culprits behind this winter's utility-bill price spike are supply and demand, a generational weather event and policy overreach in the name of climate virtue at consumers' behest.

title: Conservation Markets Can Protect Endangered Species
summary: State wildlife programs are preferable to federal Endangered Species Act intervention, but a market solution is preferable to both.. Relying on state biologists in the Western Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies (Wafwa) to protect the lesser prairie chicken hasn't worked ("Biden's Prairie Chicken Fillet," Review & Outlook, June 23).

title: You Didn't Want to Fight Muhammad Ali's Namesake
summary: Cassius Marcellus Clay had a Bowie knife and knew how to use it.. Regarding Michael Medved's op-ed "Americans Should Know the Story of Abolitionist Cassius Clay" (June 19): I want to add a point of interest about Clay. He wrote a manuscript on the techniques of fighting with a Bowie knife. When he was a U.S. minister to the czar in St. Petersburg, he was challenged to duels by Russian aristocrats who were offended by his flirting with their ladies. As the person challenged, he had the right to name the duel weapon. Of course he chose the Bowie knife. It is my understanding that they all backed down.

title: Companies Cutting Office Space Predict Long-Term Savings
summary: Some companies are taking one-time charges after agreeing to sublease some of their offices space. Companies expect to reap millions of dollars in savings in the years ahead as they scale back on office space after the coronavirus pandemic emptied workplaces around the country. However, some are paying in the short term for their decision to downsize.

title: Are Power Companies Playing Texas Hold'em?
summary: Supply is tight on the grid even before peak summer heat. Though genuine wear and tear could be the culprit, market manipulation isn't out of the question.. It isn't even close to the peak of Texas's sizzling summer season and already the state's power grid has given out two warnings of tight conditions after a higher-than-usual volume of plants went offline. Wear and tear from the February winter storm is one possible explanation; market manipulation is another. They aren't mutually exclusive.

title: Death Toll in Philippine Air Force Plane Crash Rises to 52
summary: The Lockheed C-130 Hercules with 96 soldiers and crew members aboard missed the runway at Jolo airport on Sunday. SINGAPORE-The death toll from the crash of a Philippine Air Force plane on Sunday rose to 52, including three civilians on the ground, as authorities ordered an investigation into what caused the Lockheed C-130 Hercules, commonly used for transport by militaries around the world, to go down.

title: U.S. Exit From Afghanistan Seems Illogical; Why It's Happening Anyway
summary: American political mood dictates a departure after nearly 20 years despite the myriad security and humanitarian risks. The U.S. military hasn't suffered a fatality in Afghanistan since February 2020-that is, for 16 months. So the tangible costs of staying in the country, at the reduced troop levels that had become the new normal, would have been relatively low.

title: Democrats Hope to Pass Climate Bill After Failing a Decade Ago
summary: In the face of GOP opposition, the Democratic Party emphasizes green investments as it seeks to avoid past pitfalls. WASHINGTON-The last time Democrats controlled the federal government, the party put forward a wide-ranging plan to put a price on carbon emissions, pushing to require companies to buy permits to emit carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases under a so-called "cap-and-trade" program.

title: Miami-Area Condo Owners Pushed Town for Construction Approvals Days Before Collapse
summary: 'This is holding us up,' the Champlain Towers South property manager emailed Surfside officials; town manager said no indication of need for emergency action. SURFSIDE, Fla-In the days before the collapse of Champlain Towers South, condo owners and the property manager were pressing Surfside officials to approve additional construction work that the owners intended to complete as part of the building's 40-year recertification, according to documents released Sunday by the town.

title: New York City Moves Homeless Out of Hotels as Covid-19 Rates Fall
summary: Thousands of shelter residents housed in vacant hotel rooms during the pandemic last year are being moved to other temporary quarters.

title: In Iowa Trump Country, GOP Voters Weigh Other 2024 Hopefuls
summary: Resume Subscription. ORANGE CITY, Iowa-Former President Donald Trump remains hugely popular here in Sioux County, where he won 81.8% of November's vote. But as other Republicans lay the groundwork for potential presidential bids, the area's GOP voters appear open to hearing them out.

title: You Can Visit Europe Again. Here's How to Get Around.
summary: Vacationers should stay flexible and consider travel insurance. Europe has finally swung open its door to American tourists for the first time since March 2020. But how hard is it to get there-and once you have landed, how do you cross the Continent's many borders? Is California's digital vaccination record going to ease your way past Covid-19 checks in Paris? Will New York's Excelsior Pass get you preferential treatment in Rome?

title: The Bucks and Suns Flipped a Coin for Kareem. Who Wins This Time?
summary: They were the NBA's worst teams the last time they competed with so much at stake. Now the NBA's best teams are meeting in the Finals.. The last time the Phoenix Suns and Milwaukee Bucks found themselves competing for the biggest prize in basketball, a few men in private offices huddled around telephones and listened to a coin flip.

title: Tech Firms Threaten to Quit Hong Kong Over Data Law Plan
summary: Industry group representing companies says proposed anti-doxing rules could put staff based locally at risk of criminal charges. HONG KONG- Facebook Inc., Twitter Inc. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google have privately warned the Hong Kong government that they could stop offering their services in the city if authorities proceed with planned changes to data-protection laws that could make them liable for the malicious sharing of individuals' information online.

title: Investors in Chinese Stocks Hope for Better Second Half After Weak Showing
summary: MSCI's China index had its worst first-half underperformance in eight years relative to its global benchmark. After a lackluster first half for Chinese stocks, investors and analysts are optimistic the next six months will bring better returns.

title: Credit Suisse Hires Goldman Tech Veteran in Management Revamp
summary: Joanne Hannaford joins the beleaguered Swiss lender as chief technology and operating officer. Credit Suisse Group AG hired a top technology executive from Goldman Sachs Group Inc., the latest revamp to the Swiss bank's management team in the wake of twin scandals.

title: Didi and the Big Chill on China's Big Data
summary: Beijing's crackdown shows that successfully listing, especially on a foreign stock exchange, doesn't mean a company is safe from regulators. U.S. and international investors are taking it on the nose as Beijing ramps up its crackdown on Chinese internet-technology companies-many of which are listed abroad-over data security. But in the long-run, the damage to one of China's previously fastest-growing, most dynamic sectors could be even more significant.

title: Sydney Airport Gets $17 Billion Takeover Bid
summary: Proposal for Australia's busiest airport by group of infrastructure investors signals expectations for a big post-pandemic travel recovery. SYDNEY-A group of infrastructure investors submitted a nearly $17 billion takeover bid for Sydney Airport, the operator of Australia's busiest airport, signaling that investors are willing to bet big on post-pandemic travel.

title: Midsize Pharmaceutical Firms Are the Industry's Big Deal Makers
summary: Larger peers pull back, as they pay down debt from previous sprees and resist high premiums. Midsize pharmaceutical companies are the industry's big deal makers this year, replacing larger brethren as new sources of capital emerge.

title: After Freeze, Insurance Comes Up Short for Many Texans
summary: Resume Subscription. Months after February's freeze, many Texans are still living in damaged homes after learning too late that they had inadequate insurance.

title: Retail Investors Power the Trading Wave With Record Cash Inflows
summary: Individual investors plowed a record net $27.9 billion into the U.S. stock market in June, lured by continued volatility beneath the market's surface. Retail investors keep pouring money into markets, even as many of their favorite meme stocks and cryptocurrencies have languished.

title: Apple's Tracking Rules Prompt Advertisers to Turn to Android
summary: Android ad prices have jumped, as iOS users opt out of being tracked, early data show. Advertisers have begun shifting their spending patterns in the months since Apple Inc. began requiring apps to gain iPhone and iPad users' permission to track them.

title: What Parents With Unvaccinated Kids Need to Know About the Delta Variant This Summer
summary: Is summer travel OK? How vulnerable are younger kids? Doctors answer your questions.. Gloria Kennett is eager to take a long-awaited beach vacation, but she is keeping a watchful eye on new cases of the Covid-19 Delta variant.

title: Spain's Targeting of Former Harvard Professor Provokes Trans-Atlantic Outcry
summary: Andreu Mas-Colell must pay $3.3 million penalty amid judicial crackdown on former Catalan officials accused of aiding secessionism. BARCELONA-In just two months, Andreu Mas-Colell, an internationally renowned economist and former Harvard professor, went from enjoying a peaceful retirement in his hometown of Barcelona to facing allegations by the Spanish state that could result in the seizure of his assets.

title: Apollo Considers Counterbid for U.K. Grocery Chain
summary: Offer would set up a potential bidding war with SoftBank-backed Fortress and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice. LONDON- Apollo Global Management Inc. said Monday it is considering making a bid for U.K. grocery chain Wm Morrison Supermarkets PLC, setting up a potential three-way bidding war with SoftBank Group Corp.'s Fortress Investment Group LLC and U.S. private-equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice.

title: Champlain Towers Demolished as Storm Approaches Miami
summary: Building was brought down to aid search-and-rescue work for 120 people still missing. SURFSIDE, Fla.-Officials demolished the rest of Champlain Towers South Sunday night in an effort to clear the way for search-and-rescue work for 120 missing people.

title: Container Shipping Prices Skyrocket as Rush to Move Goods Picks Up
summary: Persistent supply-chain bottlenecks are driving up rates and the shipping sector sees no relief on the horizon before 2022. Prices to ship containers from Asia to the U.S. and Europe are rising at a historic pace as cargo owners bid up rates in a search for ocean transportation capacity that shipping industry executives expect to remain tight for the rest of the year.

title: Heat Wave in Northwest Overwhelmed Healthcare System
summary: Emergency rooms overflowed, 911 calls doubled and ambulances were delayed when temperature rose above 100 for three straight days. As the temperature in Portland, Ore., soared past 100 degrees last week, Penny Clark's body temperature rose as well. After sitting inside all day without air conditioning, the 79-year-old was running a fever of 102, and the friend she was staying with called 911.

title: Biden's July 4 Gathering Celebrates Progress Against Covid-19
summary: Coronavirus cases have plummeted since winter, but vaccinations have slowed and the Delta variant is spreading rapidly. WASHINGTON-Addressing a celebratory July 4 crowd at the White House, President Biden declared that the United States is "closer than ever to declaring our independence from a deadly virus" but emphasized the importance of vaccinations.

title: America Celebrates July Fourth
summary: This holiday weekend is a turning point in the pandemic, with Americans getting back to live entertainment, large celebrations and fireworks extravaganzas. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
